gw.plugin.script

Class IScriptHost

  • gw.plugin.script.IScriptHost
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.guidewire.pl.system.integration.plugins.internal.InternalPlugin

    public class IScriptHost
implements com.guidewire.pl.system.integration.plugins.internal.InternalPlugin
    A script host for the Guidewire Scripting language (Gosu).

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Object evaluate(String strExpression)
      Evaluate a Gosu expression or program. Note symbols corresponding to entities referenced in the script (e.g., Claim) are infered by the context of the UI. For example, if the UI displays a claim file, a symbol for Claim is guarenteed to exist. If the expression is NOT entirely relavant to the UI context, you are responsible for managing the symbol dependencies via IScriptHost.evaluate( String, Object[] ) or, IScriptHost.pushScope() and IScriptHost.putSymbol().
      void executeTemplate(Reader readerTemplate, Writer writerOut)
      void popScope()
      Pop off the inner-most nested scope. Example: ... // Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber // an existing symbol with the same name. scriptHost.pushScope(); try { // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols. scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.); scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.); scriptHost.putSymbol(...); scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.); scripHost.evaluate(...); } finally { // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the // symbols in prior scope[s]. scriptHost.popScope(); }
      void pushScope()
      Push a new nested symbol scope. Example: ... // Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber // an existing symbol with the same name. scriptHost.pushScope(); try { // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols. scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.); scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.); scriptHost.putSymbol(...); scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.); scripHost.evaluate(...); } finally { // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the // symbols in prior scope[s]. scriptHost.popScope(); }
      void putSymbol(String strName, String type, Object value)
      Put a symbol into the symbol table.

      Note symbols for entities (Claim, Exposure, etc) are automatically handled in evaluate( String, Oject[] ), so most of the time you don't need to call putSymbol().

      Furthermore, you should almost always add symbols within a nested scope via IScriptHost.pushScope(). For instance, if you are adding one or more symbols before evaluating an expression or set of expressions and the symbols are relevant for only those expressions, first call pushScope() then execute your code in a try,finally block like so: ... // Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber // an existing symbol with the same name. scriptHost.pushScope(); try { // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols. scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.); scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.); scriptHost.putSymbol(...); scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.); scripHost.evaluate(...); } finally { // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the // symbols in prior scope[s]. scriptHost.popScope(); }

      void removeSymbol(String strName)
      Remove a symbol from the symbol table. Achtung! Use with care. Most of the time you should use scopes and, therefore, don't need to call removeSymbol(): ... // Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber // an existing symbol with the same name. scriptHost.pushScope(); try { // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols. scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.); scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.); scriptHost.putSymbol(...); scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.); scripHost.evaluate(...); } finally { // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the // symbols in prior scope[s]. scriptHost.popScope(); }

    • Method Detail

      • evaluate

        Object evaluate(String strExpression)
        Evaluate a Gosu expression or program. Note symbols corresponding to entities referenced in the script (e.g., Claim) are infered by the context of the UI. For example, if the UI displays a claim file, a symbol for Claim is guarenteed to exist. If the expression is NOT entirely relavant to the UI context, you are responsible for managing the symbol dependencies via IScriptHost.evaluate( String, Object[] ) or, IScriptHost.pushScope() and IScriptHost.putSymbol().
        Parameters:
        strExpression - A Gosu expression or program.
        Returns:
        The result of evaluating the expression or the return value of the program.

      • executeTemplate

        void executeTemplate(Reader readerTemplate,
                   Writer writerOut)
        Parameters:
        readerTemplate -
        writerOut -

      • popScope

        void popScope()
        Pop off the inner-most nested scope. Example: 
        ...
// Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber
// an existing symbol with the same name.
scriptHost.pushScope();
try
{
  // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols
  // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing
  // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols.
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(...);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.);
  scripHost.evaluate(...);
}
finally
{
  // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the
  // symbols in prior scope[s].
  scriptHost.popScope();
}

      • pushScope

        void pushScope()
        Push a new nested symbol scope. Example: 
        ...
// Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber
// an existing symbol with the same name.
scriptHost.pushScope();
try
{
  // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols
  // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing
  // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols.
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(...);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.);
  scripHost.evaluate(...);
}
finally
{
  // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the
  // symbols in prior scope[s].
  scriptHost.popScope();
}

      • putSymbol

        void putSymbol(String strName,
             String type,
             Object value)
        Put a symbol into the symbol table.

        Note symbols for entities (Claim, Exposure, etc) are automatically handled in evaluate( String, Oject[] ), so most of the time you don't need to call putSymbol().

        Furthermore, you should almost always add symbols within a nested scope via IScriptHost.pushScope(). For instance, if you are adding one or more symbols before evaluating an expression or set of expressions and the symbols are relevant for only those expressions, first call pushScope() then execute your code in a try,finally block like so: 

        ...
// Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber
// an existing symbol with the same name.
scriptHost.pushScope();
try
{
  // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols
  // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing
  // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols.
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(...);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.);
  scripHost.evaluate(...);
}
finally
{
  // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the
  // symbols in prior scope[s].
  scriptHost.popScope();
}
        Parameters:
        strName - The symbol's name; referencable in scripts.
        type - The symbol's type. Necessary at times when value is null, or value is a proxy, or value should be exposed only as an interface.
        value - The symbol's value.

      • removeSymbol

        void removeSymbol(String strName)
        Remove a symbol from the symbol table. Achtung! Use with care. Most of the time you should use scopes and, therefore, don't need to call removeSymbol(): 
        ...
// Calling pushScope() is a polite -- a following putSymbol() call won't clobber
// an existing symbol with the same name.
scriptHost.pushScope();
try
{
  // Because we have our own nested scope (via pushScope()) we can add symbols
  // here with no worry of clobbering the symbol table -- effectively providing
  // a safe shadowing mechanism for local symbols.
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.1.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.2.);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(...);
  scriptHost.putSymbol(.n.);
  scripHost.evaluate(...);
}
finally
{
  // popScope() removes only symbols added in this nested scope, preserving all the
  // symbols in prior scope[s].
  scriptHost.popScope();
}
        Parameters:
        strName - The name of the symbol to remove.
